title: Fury to have no coach or nutritionist for comeback
description: Tyson Fury makes his return on 11 April and believes his inactivity could play a big role in his comeback.
fullText:
Tyson Fury claims he will have no trainer for his comeback fight against Arslanbek Makhmudov.

The two-time heavyweight world champion will come out of retirement on 11 April after a year-long spell away from boxing.

American coach SugarHill Steward has trained Fury since 2019, helping him reclaim the WBC world title and coached him in the two defeats by Oleksandr Usyk.

Speaking to the 5 Live Boxing podcast with Steve Bunce, Fury said he would "do it all" by himself for his comeback training camp.

"I don't need a trainer, I don't need a nutritionist, I don't need a mind coach, I don't need a sleep coach and I definitely don't need a strength coach," he said.

"Here's what I need in boxing - someone to wash my gumshield out and give me some water between rounds, and give me a smear of Vaseline across the eyes, and leave the rest to me.

Tyson Fury: Make Boxing Great Again

'I bring a circus' - ringmaster Fury in 'prime' for Makhmudov fight

Fury retired after successive defeats by former undisputed heavyweight champion Usyk.

The 37-year-old, who has 34 wins in 37 fights including one draw, was in vintage form at his first news conference since announcing his return on Tuesday in London.

He tickled his opponent Makhmudov during their face-off and said he wanted to "make boxing great again".

Fury intends to win a world title during his comeback and dismissed claims he might struggle to sell 60,000 tickets at Tottenham Hotspur Stadium alongside the unheralded Makhmudov.

The Morecambe fighter spent two-and-a-half years out of the ring in his twenties because of a doping ban and mental health problems, but returned in 2018 after losing over 50kg and became world champion again in 2020.

"I'm 37 years old, been inactive 16 months, which is a massive factor," he said.

"I did it before with three years out the ring but I was only 29. Now I'm an older person, a pensioner really."

He added: "I bring the X factor to this game and there's nobody else alive today that can and bring more X factor to boxing than Tyson Fury."

title: What Was Michael Jordan Doing With That Kid? Viral Daytona 500 Clip Is Raising Eyebrows
description: Michael Jordan has long been a force in basketball, but his role in NASCAR keeps drawing attention. On February 15, 2026, his team, 23XI Racing, ... Read More
fullText:
Michael Jordan has long been a force in basketball, but his role in NASCAR keeps drawing attention. On February 15, 2026, his team, 23XI Racing, claimed its first Daytona 500 win with driver Tyler Reddick crossing the finish line in a thrilling last-lap push.

The race, known as NASCAR's Super Bowl, took place at Daytona International Speedway, and Reddick's victory marked a major milestone for the team Jordan co-owns with Denny Hamlin. Reddick, behind the wheel of the No. 45 Toyota, edged out competitors in a dramatic finish that had fans on their feet.

The celebrations included Reddick's family, with his six-year-old son, Beau, joining the fun. Beau has been around the racing world since he was little, often spotted at events with his dad. The energy was high, with everyone laughing and toasting the achievement. Yet, amid all this excitement, one brief interaction caught the camera's eye and quickly shifted the conversation.

During the live broadcast, a short video captured Jordan standing near Beau in the crowded Victory Lane. The footage shows Jordan making repeated pinching motions at the lower back of the boy's shirt, as if tugging or adjusting it. He also briefly brushes or rubs the back of the child's leg. The moment lasts just seconds, but it happened amid the wet, messy aftermath of champagne and ice being thrown around.

🔥🚨BREAKING: This footage of NBA legend Michael Jordan engaging with a young NASCAR fan has been going viral on every social media network. pic.twitter.com/YINERdD5sY

— Dom Lucre | Breaker of Narratives (@dom_lucre) February 16, 2026

The clip spread fast across platforms like X, Instagram, and TikTok, racking up millions of views in hours. People shared slowed-down versions and screenshots, zooming in on Jordan's hands. Captions varied from questioning to outright accusatory, with some users labeling the actions as odd or out of place. The video's context shows a soaked shirt on Beau, hinting at the celebratory mess, but that detail got lost in many reposts.

This wasn't the first time a celebrity's public moment got dissected online, but Jordan's status as an icon amplified it. Fans who watched the full broadcast noted the chaos, with people bumping into each other and drinks flying. Still, the isolated clip took on a life of its own, prompting discussions about what exactly was happening in those few frames.

The video sparked strong reactions from viewers. Some expressed discomfort, calling the interaction inappropriate and demanding explanations. Comments included phrases like "error Jordan" or "not acceptable," reflecting frustration over perceived boundaries crossed in a public setting. Critics pointed out the optics, especially in a family-oriented event like the Daytona 500, where kids are often part of the festivities.

On the other side, supporters pushed back, arguing the moment was harmless and misunderstood. They highlighted how celebrations can involve playful gestures, and many suggested Jordan was simply trying to remove ice that had slipped under Beau's shirt from the ice buckets or sprays.

One user noted, "If you watch closely, the kid's shirt is wet, and MJ is just helping out like an uncle would." Defenders also brought up similar moments in sports where athletes roughhouse with kids in good fun, without ill intent.

The debate grew heated, with memes and videos circulating. Some compared it to past celebrity controversies, while others urged caution against jumping to conclusions based on a snippet. No formal complaints emerged from the Reddick family or NASCAR, and the clip remained more of a talking point than a scandal. Still, it highlighted how quickly public figures can face scrutiny in the age of viral content.

Jordan's connection to the Reddick family runs deep, adding layers to the story. Reddick joined 23XI Racing in 2023, and Jordan has built a bond with him and his loved ones over the years. In a 2024 interview, Reddick described Jordan as a mentor figure who interacts warmly with Beau, treating him like part of the extended team. Beau, born in 2019, has grown up around Jordan at races and team events, often sharing high-fives or chats.

Team representatives addressed the clip, stating Jordan was attempting to dislodge ice from the boy's shirt, a common occurrence in those wild celebrations. Reddick himself has spoken in the past about how Jordan's involvement boosts team morale, and their relationship extends beyond the track. For instance, Jordan has attended family milestones and offered advice on balancing racing with parenthood.

This familiarity explains why the moment might seem casual to those in the know. NASCAR culture emphasizes camaraderie, with owners, drivers, and families mingling closely. The Daytona win amplified that unity, but the viral clip pulled focus from the achievement.

As of now, Jordan hasn't commented publicly, and the buzz seems contained to online discussions. The incident serves as a reminder of how context matters in high-profile moments, especially when kids are involved.

title: ‘I feel like I’m in my prime still’: Tyson Fury geared up for Arslanbek Makhmudov fight
description: Tyson Fury says he’s back to make the sport great again.
fullText:
As Tyson Fury prepares for his latest return to boxing in an April fight against Arslanbek Makhmudov, the pair held an official press conference where Fury would explain what drove his desire to return to the sport once more and the selection of his opponent.

“Why did I come back to boxing? Very, very interesting question and there’s only one answer to that,” Fury said. “And the truth of the matter is I came back for one reason only, and that’s to make boxing great again. Since I retired for the fifth time over a year ago, boxing for me has gone on a downward slope. It’s become quite boring. And boxing is at its maximum potential when Tyson Fury is actively fighting — and I didn’t say that, the cleverest AI on earth said that, ChatGPT.

“And with my I brought back the biggest streaming platform on earth, Netflix…I bring a circus, I bring an entourage, I bring entertainment, I bring action, I bring cameras. I bring everything to the sport and it’s something that I’m so passionate about, that I love.

“I was enjoying being retired…but it comes a point where you just want to go back to work. And my work will always be the fight game, no matter how old I am…I feel fresh, I feel good, and if I was on a decline I would say it. I’d be the first to say ‘I don’t got it no more’ and I won’t box, but I don’t feel as if I’ve lost anything. I feel like I’m in my prime still.

“April 11th can’t come soon enough. I’m in great shape, I’ve been training since I’ve retired — I never stopped training, it’s apart of my hobby…Makhmudov, what do I know about him? I know he’s a giant. He’s bigger than he says he is. He says he’s 6’4” but I think he’s about 6’8”, he’s a big man…If I fight a pudding, I don’t get turned on by that. I have to fight somebody dangerous to make me even want to train, make me even want to take it seriously.“

title: Jasmine Paolini explains why Dubai feels ‘Weird’ to play
description: Jasmine Paolini is looking to get her 2026 campaign going at the Dubai Tennis Championships, where she’ll open against Alexandra Eala on Tuesday. Paolini has struggled to find rhythm early in the season, exiting in the third round of the Australian Open and then falling in her opening match at the Qatar Open.
fullText:
Jasmine Paolini is looking to get her 2026 campaign going at the Dubai Tennis Championships, where she’ll open against Alexandra Eala on Tuesday.

Paolini has struggled to find rhythm early in the season, exiting in the third round of the Australian Open and then falling in her opening match at the Qatar Open.

Eala might be able to take advantage of those struggles when they meet on court.

Paolini will be hoping to find some of that form again when she takes on Eala.

The Dubai Tennis Championships return in 2026, and Jasmine Paolini’s already voiced some unusual feelings about playing there. She finds it strange how close fans are during matches, making it hard for her to settle into a rhythm.

“It feels a bit weird because I don’t like too much noise around,” she told SuperTennis. “Not even music because I can hear everything around.”

The proximity of fans isn’t new this year either; it’s been part of past events as well. Back in 2019, Halep had similar issues, pointing out that all courts are surrounded by stands with spectators positioned closely around them.

In 2024 Jasmine Paolini enjoyed a breakthrough year on the WTA Tour.

The Italian’s first significant tournament win came at the Dubai Tennis Championships. Paolini, unseeded at the event, defeated Beatriz Haddad Maia, Leylah Fernandez and Maria Sakkari on her way to the quarter-finals.

The Italian defeated Sorana Cirstea 6-2-7-6 in the semi-final setting up a clash with Anna Kalinskaya in the final.

title: Ranking the top 10 WWE men’s wrestlers ahead of the 2026 elimination chamber
description: Hello everybody, and welcome back to another week of the WWE’s Men’s Power Rankings. With only the Elimination Chamber between now and Wrestlemania, you can bet things are going to heat up once the superstars are set for the chamber.…
fullText:
Hello everybody, and welcome back to another week of the WWE’s Men’s Power Rankings. With only the Elimination Chamber between now and Wrestlemania, you can bet things are going to heat up once the superstars are set for the chamber. For now, let’s run through the list and get you caught up on some of the most recent storylines. Have a great day, everyone, and may the slams be with you.

MORE: 2026 Winter Olympics star compares muscles with NFL running back Saquon Barkley

“The Maverick” Logan Paul had another strong showing at the Royal Rumble. He looked great as always and even made it close to the end, showing that the WWE really loves his skill set. Even though Paul lost his chance to get into the Elimination Chamber last week, you can count on him getting another chance soon enough.

L.A. Knight returns to the list with his recent push and the injury to Bron Breakker, which has kept Breakker out indefinitely. On RAW last week, Knight defeated Penta and Austin Theory in a qualifying match for the Elimination Chamber. Now that the Megastar is back in the picture, you can expect the next two months to be fire. YEAH!

Instead of putting up his belt this week, Carmelo Hayes teamed up with Matt Cardona, Apollo Crews, and Ilia Dragunov against Solo Sikoa and the MFTs. In a match that was chaotic at times, the faces quickly found out why people avoid the MFTs by losing the match. I’m sure this week on SmackDown sounds good because now we have a big feud starting with a champion in the middle of it.

Dominik Mysterio has been limited due to the current storylines the WWE is pushing. However, last week on RAW, Mysterio finally returned to the WWE, which sets up nicely for the Elimination Chamber. I wouldn’t mind seeing the Intercontinental Championship put up for grabs in an Elimination Chamber, but that’s unlikely to happen right now, given the current storylines going on in the WWE.

Gunther defeated A.J. Styles in a retirement match for Styles at the Royal Rumble. Since then, he’s been trolling Styles, most recently by coming out to this entrance. This led to a fight after Dragon Lee came out once Gunther started talking badly about the WWE Universe. Since then, Gunther had been cutting promos, but I’m sure he’ll be back to his cunning ways this week.

Jey and Jimmy Uso defended their WWE Tag Team Championships against the Alpha Academy on RAW last week. In a closely contested match, the Usos were able to survive a late surge by Tozawa to retain their championships after hitting the 1-D to pin Otis. YEET!

Roman Reigns made his triumphant return to RAW two weeks after winning the Royal Rumble. After asking the WWE to acknowledge him, C.M. Punk came out to go back and forth with Reigns, which led to Reigns choosing Punk as his Wrestlemania opponent. For now, Reigns will take a break from action, making him a must-see attraction for the WWE.

Drew McIntyre has continued his path of destruction by showing up during Rhodes’ triple-threat match last week on SmackDown. Even though he didn’t inject himself into the matchup, Rhodes couldn’t contain himself and attacked McIntyre anyway. This didn’t change the fact that Rhodes still won, but during the show, McIntyre ran into Trick Williams, whom he warned to stay out of his way.

Cody Rhodes was part of a triple-threat match between Jacob Fatu, Sami Zayn, and himself. Drew McIntyre did come out during this match, in which Rhodes did go after him. Regardless, through all of the shenanigans, Rhodes came out victorious, cashing his ticket in for the Elimination Chamber.

C.M. Punk came out to do a promo with Michael Cole, but that was short-lived once Finn Balór came out. Balór demanded a rematch at Elimination Chamber in Chicago, in which Punk accepted. After that, Punk then addressed Roman Reigns and reassured everyone that he isn’t worried about taking a title match before his match with Reigns at Wrestlemania.

title: What Tudor must do to win over 'increasingly apathetic fanbase'
description: Is hiring Igor Tudor a stroke of genius or a disastrous appointment by the board?  On the one hand, the Croat has a reasonably impressive track record of improving teams over a short-term period.  Ultimately, as long as Tudor can do enough to keep us in the Premier League, I am not particularly fussed.
fullText:
Is hiring Igor Tudor a stroke of genius or a disastrous appointment by the board?

The fact that no-one seems able to answer this question with any great conviction has done nothing to either calm my nerves or excite me.

On the one hand, the Croat has a reasonably impressive track record of improving teams over a short-term period. Essentially, this is all we really need from him so we can avoid relegation, before we appoint a permanent head coach in the summer.

However, Tudor is also known for his high-intensity style of play, with training sessions and fitness work testing players to their limits.

Normally this would not concern me, but given our current injury crisis and ongoing issues within our medical department, I am not sure the ghost of Antonio Conte past is the wisest approach right now.

Ultimately, as long as Tudor can do enough to keep us in the Premier League, I am not particularly fussed.

However, therein lies the problem.

As a fan, I was excited to see who the board would call upon to rescue our season.

I appreciate the options were limited, given we needed someone who was available on a short-term basis mid-season, but this was also a priceless opportunity to unite an increasingly apathetic fanbase.

If we are to play our part in redeeming this season, we need to feel invested in our team.

Hopefully Tudor can win us over by inspiring – or scaring – the players into delivering something we have been missing so far in this campaign: football that is worth watching.

Get us scoring some goals, winning some games, and keep us in the league.

Then we can bring home everyone's favourite Argentine in the summer and forget this sorry season ever happened.

Find more from Ali Speechly at Women Of The Lane and on Instagram

title: 3 Explosive Reasons To Watch ONE Friday Fights 143 On February 20
description: Here's why you shouldn't miss this Asian primetime card at Lumpinee Stadium on February 20.
fullText:
ONE Championship continues its surging 2026 campaign with ONE Friday Fights 143 on February 20, another stacked card designed to thrill fans from the opening bell to the final horn.

Broadcasting live in Asia primetime from Bangkok’s iconic Lumpinee Stadium, this showcase features explosive Muay Thai and kickboxing battles that promise non-stop action and career-defining moments.

International stars look to cement their cases for a life-changing US$100,000 contract, while some aim to reignite their campaigns with statement performances.

Before the opening bell rings inside the Madison Square Garden of the East, here are three reasons why ONE Friday Fights 143 demands your attention.

Israeli slugger Shir Cohen returns to the ring in search of her fourth consecutive victory, and another dominant performance could position her for a shot at ONE Championship gold.

The 25-year-old Fairtex Training Center representative has looked nothing short of spectacular throughout her promotional journey. She’s gone a perfect 3-0 with performances that have showcased her evolution as a complete striker, blending technical precision with devastating power that’s made her one of the most dangerous women in the division.

The timing couldn’t be better for the Israeli slugger to make her statement, as the ONE Women’s Atomweight Muay Thai World Title is set to be contested when divisional queen Allycia Hellen Rodrigues faces “The Queen” Phetjeeja in the main event of ONE Fight Night 41 on Prime Video.

A fourth straight victory would make Cohen’s case undeniable and put her on the doorstep of the biggest opportunity of her career once more after an injury forced her to withdraw from her World Title fight against Rodrigues in June last year. However, standing in her path to title contention is one of Myanmar’s most dangerous striking exports, Vero.

The 29-year-old veteran enters this atomweight Muay Thai showdown at ONE Friday Fights 143 riding momentum from back-to-back victories over Junior Fairtex and Li “Miracle Girl” Mingrui. She brings veteran savvy, proven finishing ability, and experience – exactly the type of test Cohen needs to pass to continue her ascent.

Vero possesses the tools to derail the Israeli’s momentum and inject herself into the ONE World Title picture with an upset victory. But no one has been able to slow down the Fairtex Training Center warrior thus far, and she’ll look to keep that plot intact in this must-watch showdown.

Thai dynamo Anon Taladkondernmuangpon has wasted zero time making an impact since arriving at ONE, building a 2-0 resume on two ferocious finishes. He returns to Lumpinee looking to make it three straight finishes and strengthen his case for the US$100,000 contract and a spot on the main roster.

He needed just two rounds to demolish Samsiblan Sor Sasawat at ONE Friday Fights 115. Then, three months later, he gave Belgian finishing machine Gianny “The Lion of Flanders” De Leu a taste of his own medicine with another second-round knockout to move to 82-20 in his career.

The N&P Boxing Gym affiliate combines technical precision with devastating power, making him one of the most exciting fighters in the division. However, Teeyai Torfunfarm, a battle-tested veteran, enters this strawweight Muay Thai tilt hungry for redemption.

The Thai striker sits on a three-fight losing streak, but dismissing him would be a critical mistake. Teeyai opened his ONE Championship tenure with back-to-back highlight-reel victories that showcased exactly the type of finishing power that could derail Anon’s perfect run on the global stage.

Knockout power exists on both sides, making this a high-risk, high-reward encounter for both men. Anon seeks to maintain perfection and edge closer to his contract, while Teeyai aims to play spoiler and return to winning ways inside Lumpinee.

When two strikers with proven finishing ability meet under these circumstances, the only guarantee is that someone’s night will end early.

Nakrob Fairtex and Panrit Lukjaomaesaiwaree collide in a bantamweight Muay Thai showdown that has barnburner written all over it.

Between them, these two veterans have accumulated 27 promotional appearances, and if there’s one guarantee, it’s that they’ve consistently delivered value for every second of screen time.

Already contracted Nakrob has built his reputation on thrilling three-round wars and spectacular knockouts throughout his campaign in the world’s largest martial arts organization.

Panrit is no different. The Superbon Training Camp slugger has emerged victorious inside the distance with his dangerous match-finishing power. The 29-year-old has looked equally solid in several fights that went down to the wire.

For Nakrob, this represents another opportunity to showcase why he’s already earned his spot on ONE Championship’s main roster. On Panrit’s end, the stakes couldn’t be higher: an impressive victory over a contracted athlete would dramatically strengthen his case for the life-changing six-figure contract that remains just out of reach.

As such, for as long as this clash lasts expect fireworks, drama, and the type of all-action war that could steal the show when the organization returns to the Thai capital with another blockbuster ONE Friday Fights card on February 20.

title: PREVIEW: Benfica look to surprise Real Madrid again in playoff round first leg
description: Real Madrid visit Benfica for the first leg of the Champions League playoff round just weeks after the Portuguese side’s surprise victory denied Los Blancos automatic qualification to the round of 1...
fullText:
Real Madrid visit Benfica for the first leg of the Champions League playoff round just weeks after the Portuguese side’s surprise victory denied Los Blancos automatic qualification to the round of 16 at the Estadio da Luz.

The hosts made the playoffs on goal difference after finishing 24th in the league phase, courtesy of their barnstorming 4-2 win over Madrid with goalkeeper Anatoliy Trubin heading home in the dying minutes to close out a classic.

With three wins and five losses in eight games, Jose Mourinho’s side have been inconsistent but have shown just enough quality to stay in the competition and have gone unbeaten in their last five league outings, winning four.

Their latest encouraging result, a 2-1 win at Santa Clara, has given the team a confidence boost before this important match.

The home crowd could give Benfica a genuine advantage with the energy they bring, while Álvaro Arbeloa’s Madrid have sometimes struggled away in Europe.

Benfica scored 10 goals and conceded 12 in the league phase, showing they’ve attacked well but are leaky in defense – all of their last five Champions League games have ended with a winner, so draws are rare for them.

But the triumph over Madrid in the final round of the league phase for As Águias was their best moment in Europe this season, proving they can take advantage of the top team’s defensive weaknesses and be competitive.

They will try to repeat that performance and get a good result in the first leg.

Benfica might be missing several players, with Alexander Bah back in training after a long knee injury, but he may not be ready yet.

Samuel Soares could miss the game with a muscle problem, and Fredrik Aursnes is also expected to be out.

Joao Veloso’s condition remains uncertain, and even though Richard Rios has returned to training after a shoulder injury, he probably will not play.

Much like their opponents, Madrid arrive in Lisbon in a confident mood given their form in La Liga – picking up four of their last five games, including a 4-1 win over Real Sociedad where Vinícius Júnior bagged a brace.

However, their European campaign has been tougher. Madrid finished ninth with 15 points from eight games, winning five and losing three.

And two wins and three losses in their last five Champions League games is below their usual standard.

Madrid’s earlier loss to Benfica showed their defensive issues on the transition, which Arbeloa’s team need to keep in mind if they are to avoid a repeat of their damaging loss three weeks ago.

Arbeloa could employ a more careful approach in Lisbon, aiming to exact more control on the tie – especially with so much at stake.

When teams are evenly matched, their ability to control the game and make the most of key moments can be decisive.

If Benfica leave gaps in defense, Madrid – who often do well in high-pressure matches like this – have the quality to exploit them and possibly take charge before the second leg.

Kylian Mbappé, who missed the win over Sociedad, is now fit and could play, but Raul Asencio is suspended after being shown a second yellow card in the final league phase clash.

Rodrygo is also suspended, having been handed a two-match ban handed out by UEFA for directing “insulting and abusive language” at the match officials, a costly mistake that means he will miss both legs of the play-off.

Madrid are also without England international Jude Bellingham, who is out with a hamstring injury, and Eder Militao is still recovering from a tendon problem.

title: Surprising day jobs of 15 American Olympians
description: When people picture Olympians, they often imagine full-time athletes whose lives revolve entirely around training, travel, and competition. The reality, however, is far more complex — and often far more relatable. For many American Olympians, elite sport does not come…
fullText:
When people picture Olympians, they often imagine full-time athletes whose lives revolve entirely around training, travel, and competition. The reality, however, is far more complex — and often far more relatable. For many American Olympians, elite sport does not come with the kind of financial stability people assume. Sponsorships can be limited, prize money inconsistent, and training expenses constant. As a result, many athletes build parallel careers that look surprisingly ordinary — or, in some cases, completely unexpected.

Some balance technical professions that demand intense mental focus, while others work hands-on jobs that require physical endurance very different from their sport. A few take on roles connected to their athletic world, but many step into industries that seem worlds away from Olympic arenas. From engineering labs and finance offices to artistic studios and equipment workshops, these day jobs reveal a side of Olympians rarely seen during televised competitions.

What makes these stories compelling is not just the contrast, but the discipline required to sustain both worlds at once. Training schedules, recovery routines, and international travel must coexist with deadlines, customers, and professional responsibilities. In many cases, these careers are not temporary stopgaps but meaningful pursuits that provide stability, identity, and long-term direction beyond sport.

Looking at the surprising day jobs of 15 American Olympians offers a powerful reminder: behind the extraordinary performances are individuals navigating very practical realities — working professionals who chase excellence both on the clock and on the world stage.

Ryan Cochran-Siegle helps run his family’s maple syrup farm in Vermont when he’s not racing down mountains. The physical, hands-on nature of farm work mirrors the endurance and discipline he needs in alpine skiing. It’s a grounded lifestyle that keeps him connected to family traditions even while competing on the world stage.

Korey Dropkin works in real estate, helping clients buy and sell homes while also competing internationally in curling. He’s described juggling two full-time commitments — negotiating deals off the ice and chasing medals on it. The flexibility of real estate makes it one of the few careers that can adapt to Olympic-level travel.

Cory Thiesse works in a wastewater testing lab, analyzing chemicals as part of environmental monitoring. Her scientific job provides stability and helps fund her training schedule. Balancing precision in lab work with precision on the curling sheet shows just how structured her daily life must be.

Park City's Paige Jones ski jumps in mixed team at the Milano Cortina Olympics https://t.co/DHb1ctesFQ pic.twitter.com/ymsMhCMEjE

— TownLift (@TownLiftNews) February 13, 2026

Paige Jones is pursuing a degree in biomedical engineering alongside Olympic ski jumping. She has said academics help her mentally reset from the intense focus of competition. Her studies also hint at a long-term career path beyond sport, showing how Olympians often prepare for life after the Games.

Morelle McCane has worked several jobs, including performing as a children’s birthday party clown. It’s a striking contrast to her fierce persona in the boxing ring. The mix of gigs reflects the hustle many athletes rely on to finance their Olympic dreams.

Bradley Wilson sells artwork to help pay for his skiing career. What began as a creative hobby during the offseason turned into a genuine income stream. His artistic side offers both financial support and a mental break from the intensity of competition.

Chris Plys runs his late father’s food brokerage business while competing in curling. Managing a company requires leadership and decision-making — skills that translate well to high-pressure matches. His dual role shows how family responsibilities and elite sport often overlap.

Lea Ann Parsley works as a firefighter, a job that demands strength, composure, and quick reactions. Those same qualities are essential in skeleton racing, where split-second decisions matter. Her career embodies a literal commitment to service both on and off the track.

Susan Dunklee works in environmental science, focusing on issues related to conservation and ecology. Her profession aligns naturally with her outdoor sport, which depends on pristine winter landscapes. It reflects a personal investment in protecting the environments where she trains and competes.

Tabitha Peterson works in pharmacy, helping patients manage medications and health care needs. The attention to detail required in dispensing prescriptions mirrors the precision of elite curling. Her medical career provides both financial security and meaningful work beyond sport.

Tara Peterson practices dentistry while competing internationally. The technical skill and steady hands needed in dental work parallel the control required in curling strategy and delivery. Her career shows how athletes can maintain highly specialized professions alongside elite competition.

Alex Deibold works as a snowboard wax technician, preparing boards so they perform optimally in changing snow conditions. The job keeps him deeply connected to the technical side of the sport, even when he’s not competing. His expertise with equipment gives him an insider’s understanding of performance that many athletes never fully develop.

Kimi Goetz works part-time as a processor at a finance company, handling paperwork and transactions between training sessions. The role demands accuracy and focus — skills that translate directly to the precision required in elite speed skating. Her office work helps provide steady income while she pursues competition at the highest level.

Keely Cashman works as a barista at her family’s coffee shop. The job keeps her grounded in everyday routines when she’s not racing internationally. It’s a reminder that even elite athletes often return to ordinary work between competitions.

Austin Florian works as an aerospace engineer, applying advanced physics and engineering principles in a highly technical professional environment. His analytical mindset and problem-solving skills mirror the precision and control required in skeleton racing. Balancing a demanding STEM career with Olympic training highlights the intellectual and physical discipline he maintains year-round.

These athletes remind us that Olympic greatness doesn’t exist in isolation from everyday life. Their day jobs reveal resilience, adaptability, and determination that extend far beyond competition. Whether managing businesses, working technical roles, or supporting communities, they embody the idea that excellence can thrive in multiple arenas at once. Their stories make the Olympic journey feel not just inspiring, but deeply human.

title: Galatasaray vs Juventus – Predicted lineup and team news
description: Galatasaray take on Juventus in the first leg of their Champions League play-off tie tonight.The Turkish champions are into the competition’s knockout rounds for the first time in over a decade and ...
fullText:
Galatasaray take on Juventus in the first leg of their Champions League play-off tie tonight.

The Turkish champions are into the competition’s knockout rounds for the first time in over a decade and face a glamour tie against the Italian giants.

Galatasaray head into the contest in good form after four consecutive wins, including a 5-1 thrashing of Eyupspor on Friday. Mauro Icardi hit a hat-trick in that fixture.

Mario Lemina will miss the clash against his former team through suspension, leaving a gap in the Galatasaray midfield. Head coach Okan Buruk could opt to reinstate Gabriel Sara, or unleash in-form forwards Icardi and Victor Osimhen as a pair in Istanbul.

Icardi and Osimhen have each scored 15 goals in all competitions this season, with the latter netting six in the Champions League alone.

There’s further flair in the form of Leroy Sane, who has recently returned to training after injury, and January recruits Noa Lang and Yaser Asprilla. Sacha Boey also returned to the club for a second spell in the winter window, on loan from German giants Bayern Munich.

Galatasaray remain without Metahan Baltaci, who is banned due to his involvement in a Turkish betting scandal.

Galatasaray predicted XI: Cakir; Sallai, Bardakci, Sanchez, Jakobs; Yilmaz, Torreira, Gundogan, Lang; Icardi, Osimhen.

Galatasaray vs Juventus will kick-off in Istanbul at 17:45 GMT.

The Galatasaray v Juventus game will be shown live in the UK on TNT Sports 1.

title: Cedric Coward Q&A: 'Ja Morant is one of the best people I've ever met'
description: Cedric Coward spoke in depth about the adjustments in his rookie season, why he wants to work out with Kawhi Leonard, the public misconceptions about Ja Morant, where he was when Jaren Jackson Jr was traded, and more.
fullText:
Cedric Coward has had a whirlwind of a rookie season, navigating constant Ja Morant trade rumors, the stunning departure of his most influential mentor in Jaren Jackson Jr., and the pressures of immediate NBA production. On the court, he's exceeded expectations quickly, averaging over 13.3 ppg and 6.2 rpg on 46.8 percent shooting, production that earned him a spot in the Rising Stars game in Los Angeles.

While in town for All-Star Weekend, Coward stopped by the Panini Prizm VIP lounge, where he spoke in depth about the adjustments of his rookie year, why he wants to work out with Kawhi Leonard, the public misconceptions about Morant, where he was when Jackson was traded, and more.

Cedric Coward: It's going along great. It's filled with ups and downs, but at the same time, I think it's on the uptrend. I'm super happy. I'm super blessed to be here to be a part of this entire thing, especially All-Star Weekend, being one of the select few, but the job's not done. I still got much more I need to do.

CC: I think it's been an ongoing conversation we've been having. Like I said, I trust them. I trust the training staff. I trust Coach because if you really think about it, I didn't even play a college season last year. I only played six games. So I was still in like catch-up mode and going from six games to almost a year layoff, to trying to play 82, that takes a toll on your body. But at the same time, I do as much as I can to help mediate that process so I can play each and every game possible. But at the same time, I trust those guys. I trust everybody in that room right there. And then it's ongoing conversations we have all the time.

CC: I think it was one of our third or fourth back-to-back. You're not used to playing a back-to-back unless you're in AAU. But that's once every weekend, maybe. But in the NBA, it can come up quick. You can play four games in five days. So I ended up playing in a back-to-back, and I didn't feel as tired as I did in the previous back-to-back. So I was like, "Oh, okay, cool. I'm starting to get used to the grind, and how to take better care of your body, and how to really manage sleep." And all these different things that help you perform that and become way, way better at it.

CC: Oh, I knew I belonged in the league when I got drafted. Not to be arrogant, but at the same time, when I got drafted, I felt a sense of like, "I deserved to be here." It took so much hard work to get to this point, just like everyone else, but what I went through personally - you’re climbing mountains, not hills but just climbing mountains.

CC: Nah, man, you gotta be a little crazy to realize and accomplish your dreams. I never had any doubt in myself. I never had any doubt in what was happening. Obviously, there was a lot of roadblocks in the way, but at the same time, you just gotta get around it.

I'm super blessed. I have great people in my corner that kept encouraging me, making sure I was taking care of business, especially after the shoulder injury. And I have a great team of agency and team around me as well that got my name out there enough. So now all I had to do was go perform on the court. All I did was wanna make an impact. I wasn't trying to go out and score a certain amount of points, get a certain amount of rebounds, nothing. I just wanted to go make an impact and do what I can on the court to help the team win. If I score 50 or if I score five, as long as we win, that's the only thing I care about.

CC: What do you define as a bad game, though? Because if you score a lot of points and you lose, it can say you had a good game because you scored a lot of points, but you lost. Or if you score a little amount of points and you win, you can say you had a bad game because you scored a little amount of points, but you won.

So for me, I always go and base the game I had on the result first and just the process of the game. If I was getting the shots I wanted and I was making the right passes and maybe stuff didn't fall, and I had three points and I was 2 for 10, but I got the shot that I wanted, I'll say it's a decent game. Now I just got to make the shots.

CC: You're playing with the best players in the world. I mean, basketball is a very fine line between the best players in the world and the ones who are in the NBA but aren't up to that caliber yet. But it's a huge gap between NBA players and everybody else. So going from college, not playing since November, and then my first game being back, being in the NBA was a complete and total adjustment. You had to go out there with confidence and you have to go out there with a sense of belonging or else you will get embarrassed. But at the same time, for me, that's probably the biggest adjustment, understanding that this caliber of players is everybody, one through 15, not one through five. And then you have the drop of knowledge, one through 15.

CC: Yes, I have. We played the Warriors. Steph Curry hit me with a surplus of dribble moves, stepped back three on the left wing, and splashed it. And then did his little shimmy thing, running back down the court. And for me, watching on TV, it seemed so fun. It seemed so cool. But then getting scored on, I was like, 'Yeah, this not that fun anymore.'

CC: Nothing to that status because I felt like I was right there in his face and it didn't matter. And I was like, this was legit, he just didn't see me. When I was guarding KD, he just shot over me. Like I've never had anybody do that in my life. But you know, those Hall-of-Fame caliber players, man.

CC: Yeah, for sure. The time I asked if I can work out with him, he said, 'Yeah, let's do it.' And then the next time I saw him, I asked again and made sure like it was okay. Now we just got to get connected. But honestly, man, I live by the motto, closed mouths don't get fed. And for me, I'm compared to him a lot. And obviously, there's one Kawhi Leonard, and then there's one Cedric Coward. But at the same time, if I can learn from greats like that, if I can learn from guys that are All-Stars and I can add what they have into my game and mold myself with them along with many others, then that can only be beneficial.

So even if I look like a PR dude at the time, that's okay. He didn't deny me, so it's cool.

CC: Not really. But there's definitely a list, there's definitely so many people I do want to work with and want to gain as much knowledge from. Not only mentally but physically understanding how they take care of their body. I mean, LeBron is in year 23. One of my things is, I want to understand when I'm able to have a conversation with him how he took care of his body.

Obviously you hear the stories but it's better to hear from the source. Obviously you look what drills Steph Curry does to get shots, especially guarded. What drills or what footwork does Kevin Durant do? There’s so many things from so many different people that I would like to take and I’m just waiting for the opportunity.

CC: Not one particular one. There was, but unfortunately, he's passed away, and that was Kobe Bryant.

CC: Man, I miss Trip tremendously. Didn't know him for long in terms of actual time of the relationship, but it feels like I've known him forever. Just because I was a lot like him and he was a lot like me. We're goofy people. We're the life of the party in terms bringing energy to the room. And honestly, he was like my first vet. He was the one that really would drop random bits of knowledge on me all the time. I would really listen because he's been successful in this league. I mean, All-NBA, All-Star, Defensive Player of the Year... You should listen to guys like that. And for me, whenever he would drop that knowledge on me, I felt like I needed to listen to it because he doesn't have to do this.

But I want all the best for him, man, for the rest of his career, for everything. We're keeping in touch and making sure that he plays great throughout the whole season until he plays us. And then he has a bad game. But then, besides that, man, that's my guy.

CC: I was right next to him. We were walking up the stairs, going to practice, and next thing you know, he's turning around, walking down the stairs. And I was like, "Oh, okay, what's going on?" Next thing you know, you hear the news from our coaches. And then we just shared a moment in the locker room. You're like brothers, man. And that's where all my teammates, Vince [Williams], Jock [Landale], Jitty [John Konchar], like all of them, like you share a moment with those guys, like understanding what they meant to you. Even though you didn't know them long, they got a special place in my heart for sure.

CC: Yeah, it depends what people think about him. If you want to say all the negative connotations about him, you're dead wrong and you need to keep your thoughts to yourself. Ja is one of the best people I've ever met. One of the best people to be around. He's the same way, goofy - we quote movies all the time. I mean, he's always cracking jokes.

What people portray him to be is not what he is. He'll take care of you in terms of like, when we had the ice storm, he offered to buy my groceries, just little things like that he doesn't have to do, but he does out of the kindness of his own heart and just taking care of people, just because that's who he is. That's like his nature. And then at the same time, he's just a great person to be around. Like I tell people all the time, he's one of the people I'd bring to my cookout, you know, and you'd be like, "Hey man, come on through." You know what I'm saying? And everybody would love him.

CC: Ah, man. A lot of old school movies. I say 'Friday'. Friday's probably a good one. I mean, we've quoted like 'Paid in Full' before, we've quoted 'Juice', we've quoted so many things I can't even name them. But 'Friday' is probably the most recent one I can remember.

CC: I'm out here with Panini at the Prizm Lounge they got here in LA, signing cards, meeting new people, meeting the same people I already knew, and building relationships and just having fun in the process.

CC: Me personally, I didn't, but I know many, many people who did. My grandpa is one of them. Very close. So the fact that I can sign my own cards and he collects them, and I'd be a part of the collection, is super special to me. He's out here in LA too, so he's not here with me, but he knows I'm out here.

CC: Oh man, it was a surreal feeling. People collect these cards as hobbies and sometimes as jobs, and for me to be a part of that card-collecting culture and people are searching for my signature. I think it's super special to know that you're making an impact in people's lives.

This article originally appeared on Hoops Hype: Cedric Coward Q&A: 'Ja Morant is one of the best people I've ever met'

title: Welcome back: Bove’s journey back to the field
description: In December 2024 fans in the Stadio Artemio Franchi and watching worldwide feared the worst for Edoardo Bove. Giancarlo Rinaldi looks at his incredible journey back to the field of play.On a weekend o...
fullText:
In December 2024 fans in the Stadio Artemio Franchi and watching worldwide feared the worst for Edoardo Bove. Giancarlo Rinaldi looks at his incredible journey back to the field of play.

On a weekend of Italian football dominated by the usual controversy, gamesmanship and conspiracy theories, there was some sunshine that broke through from the unlikely location of Preston’s Deepdale stadium. Late in the game, Watford made a substitution which will have made supporters of Fiorentina, Roma and Serie A in general smile. Edoardo Bove stepped back into a competitive game – something which seemed unthinkable to anyone who witnessed his dramatic collapse in the clash with Inter more than 14 months ago.

FLORENCE, ITALY – DECEMBER 23: Edoardo Bove of ACF Fiorentina looks on during the Serie A match between Fiorentina and Udinese at Stadio Artemio Franchi on December 23, 2024 in Florence, Italy. (Photo by Gabriele Maltinti/Getty Images)

It was just a few minutes for his new club, Watford, but it still felt special. He was clearly delighted to be back doing what he loved after so long away and itching to make up for lost time. The fact that it all seemed so unlikely only makes it more welcome.

Anyone watching that Fiorentina-Inter game would have worried for his life, never mind his playing career. The distressing scenes after he fell to the ground off the ball were the kind nobody expects or wants to see at a football game. It seemed to take an eternity for emergency services to get to him and rush him from the stadium for treatment. In truth, it only took 13 minutes for doctors to take Bove to the Careggi hospital, on the opposite side of the city. Only gradually did more encouraging news filter through.

Edoardo Bove of ACF Fiorentina looks on during the Serie A match between Fiorentina and FC Internazionale at Stadio Artemio Franchi on February 6, 2025 in Florence, Italy. (Photo by Gabriele Maltinti/Getty Images)

Still, there were question marks about his recovery – how long it would take and how complete it might be. The fitting of a defibrillator meant that his playing days in Italy were over due to strict regulations on such things. While it was delightful to see him back on the bench with Fiorentina, he cut a bit of a forlorn figure. Glad to be alive, of course, but struggling to come to terms with watching the sport he had dedicated his life to and being unable to take part. Like seeing something you had always longed for dangling tantalisingly out of reach.

Let us not forget that Bove was in fine form – as was his club – at the moment he was forced to take his unwanted break. He was a driving force in the Viola midfield, and there were certainly some who were suggesting the Italian national team could do with a player of his intensity and energy. Then, suddenly, it was all taken away. Fiorentina’s form stuttered as the young player began his lengthy rehabilitation process.

He appeared on the sidelines, he popped up at Wimbledon to support his good friend tennis ace Fabio Cobolli, but always with a slight hint of melancholy about him. Having lived and breathed football for most of his life, it must have been frustrating to be forced to put his boots away. Many players talk about how difficult retirement can be, even after a lengthy career – that must have been multiplied when it was being forced on him so early.

Edoardo Bove of Italy during the UEFA U21 EURO Qualifier match between Italy and Norway at Stadio Druso on October 17, 2023 in Bolzen, Italy. (Photo by Alessandro Sabattini/Getty Images)

That’s why Saturday afternoon at about 4.44pm in Lancashire was a moment watched with interest and delight in Florence, Rome and much of Italy. At just 23 years of age, Bove can still have a lengthy career ahead of him – even if it cannot be in Serie A. It might not be a perfect solution, but it is a whole lot better than everyone feared on that fateful winter evening in Tuscany more than 400 days ago.

Just to watch him back playing the game felt like arriving home after a very long journey. There will be tough times to come, no doubt, but simply seeing the young Roman kick a ball again will more than suffice for now. We can sometimes get carried away about football and forget what really matters in life and how precious every moment should be. That’s why his return to action is about so much more than simply what position he plays or what contribution he can make in terms of tackles, goals or assists. Just being out there on the pitch is a victory in itself. Bentornato Edo.

title: Chelsea defender cites Liverpool duo as role models
description: Chelsea defender Mamadou Sarr has called Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk his role model and has outlined his ambition ‘to be the best centre-back in the world’.Sarr has returned to Chelsea after...
fullText:
Chelsea defender Mamadou Sarr has called Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk his role model and has outlined his ambition ‘to be the best centre-back in the world’.

Sarr has returned to Chelsea after head coach Liam Rosenior cut short his loan spell at Strasbourg.

The 20-year-old had impressed under Rosenior’s management at the French side and formed part of the Senegal team that won the Africa Cup of Nations earlier this year.

He made his first appearance of the season as Chelsea won 4-0 at Hull City in the FA Cup on Friday night. The defender looked at home in the Blues’ backline, as Chelsea recorded a clean sheet in the fourth-round tie.

Discussing his return to Chelsea and future goals, Sarr opened up on the players he is aiming to emulate. He named Van Dijk as a role model, but believes his game has comparisons with Van Dijk’s Liverpool teammate, Ibrahima Konate.

“I want to be like Virgil van Dijk. I love Van Dijk. They called me that when I was younger,” he said to ESPN.

“But some people also tell me I play like Ibrahima Konate. It’s very similar. He’s a leader. For a defender, it’s very important to be a leader. Off and on the pitch, I talk a lot. It’s an important job. I think I anticipate well.

“With the ball, I can pick a good pass. When I was a kid, I had a dream. It was to be the best centre-back in the world.”

title: Seahawks get bad news on bringing back Super Bowl MVP Kenneth Walker
description: Seattle can't do everything all at once.
fullText:
Seahawks get bad news on bringing back Super Bowl MVP Kenneth Walker originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Seattle Seahawks are in a bit of a bind.

It could cost them the Super Bowl MVP.

Kenneth Walker stole the show in Seattle's win over the New England Patriots to claim the Lombardi Trophy.

Now, though, he's a free agent. And bringing him back might not be as easy as Seahawks fans would like.

Walker could be franchise-tagged, but that is unlikely, according to ESPN's Adam Schefter.

"It’s unlikely the Seahawks will use their franchise tag running back and Super Bowl MVP Kenneth Walker, per league sources," Schefter wrote on X on Tuesday morning. "The Seahawks have multiple free agents they want to retain and sign. They also will try to extend WR Jaxon Smith-Njigba. There are enough Super-Bowl tax costs that now make using a franchise tag this off-season unlikely."

For starters, the franchise tag for running backs is likely a little too rich for what Walker's true value is.

There's also the matter of RB contracts in the modern NFL in general. Except for the very best guys, it can be tough to reach agreements on fair compensation at a position that sees a lot of turnover each and every season.

And then, as Schefter writes, there's only so much money to go around.

A JSN extension will cost the Seahawks a fortune, and they've got to figure out which of their pending free agents they want back.

Walker played a great game in the biggest game of his life, but that doesn't guarantee him anything, especially as a running back in the year 2026.

title: Pens Points: Knockouts Begin
description: Get ready for the Olympic knockouts with Pens Points.
fullText:
It’s do-or-die time in Milan as the Olympic Men’s ice hockey tournament enters the knockout stages of competition, beginning today with four games that will set the Quarterfinal round set to take place on Wednesday. Thus far, Canada, The United States, Slovakia, and Finland have booked places in the quarters based on their performances in the group play. That leaves the remaining eight sides to battle it out in a playoff round to sort out the other four quarterfinalists.

Play begins on Tuesday at 6:10 AM EST with Germany v. France and Switzerland v. Italy. Then it’s Czechia v. Denmark at 10:40 AM EST before Sweden v. Latvia wraps up the day at 3:40 PM EST.

Three of the Penguins Olympic representatives will be in action on Tuesday, all looking to keep their medal hopes alive and advance to the quarterfinals. Erik Karlsson and Rickard Rakell hope to keep Sweden in contention and set up a showdown with the United States while going up against Arturs Silovs and Latvia. [Pensburgh]

The last time we saw the Pittsburgh Penguins in action, Avery Hayes was making his NHL debut and scoring two big goals in a game against the Buffalo Sabres. Hayes was sent back to the AHL for the Olympic break, but his stay back in the minors may only be temporary. [Pensburgh]

Ville Koivunen has spent time between the AHL and NHL this season as his development continues to progress. Right now he’s in Wilkes-Barre and tearing up the league with 13 points in his last nine games as he helps the Baby Penguins battle for a playoff bye in the standings. [The Hockey News]

In a classic Kyle Dubas move, the Penguins bought (relatively) low on former first round draft pick Egor Chinakhov who was looking for a change of scenery away from Columbus. Since coming to PIttsburgh, Chinakhov has looked every bit of a former first round selection. [The Hockey News]

Another potential Dubas reclamation project came in the form of defenseman Ilya Solovyov, acquired from the Colorado Avalanche in January. After being scratched his first three games after the trade, Solovyov has worked his way into the lineup and is hoping his spot becomes permanent. [Trib Live]

If the Penguins are going to be making move at the trade deadline, it seems the most likely assests they are willing to part with are draft picks, just not their 2026 first round pick unless they are blown away. Given their position in the standings, it seems unlikely any players are on the block. [The Athletic $$]

Brandon Bussi has been a breakout star for the Carolina Hurricanes this season and they aren’t letting him get away. On Monday, the Hurricanes and Bussi agreed to a three-year contract extension that will keep the former waiver wire pickup in Raleigh long term. [Sportsnet]

Jeff Skinner will be looking for a new home once the NHL resumes play next week. Skinner and the San Jose Sharks have agreed to part ways as the forward was placed on waivers for the purpose of having his contract terminated, making him a free agent. [The Hockey News]

Not that there was much doubt coming into the Olympics, but the United States and Canada will face-off for gold in the women’s tournament after both sides won their respective semifinal contests on Monday. The gold medal game is scheduled for Thursday at 1:10 PM EST. [Yahoo!]

title: Iowa State beats Houston in instant classic as both show off Final Four potential
description: Iowa State needed it all against Houston, who matched it punch for punch for almost the entire game. Both teams are no-doubt Final Four contenders.
fullText:
AMES, Iowa – Sixth-ranked Iowa State made plays big and small, though always critical, to turn a 10-point second-half deficit into a 70-67 victory — a beautiful, wonderful and incredible victory — over No. 2 Houston on Feb. 17.

“Stepping up and having the courage to make the plays that need to be made,” future Hall of Famer and Houston coach Kelvin Sampson said, “they did tonight, and we didn’t.”

The moment that will always lead any discussion about this instant classic will, undoubtedly, be Nate Heise’s go-ahead 3-pointer with 77 ticks of the clock remaining.

NCAA tournament bracketology: UConn rises in projection as Selection Sunday nears

Earlier in the half, Heise briefly lost vision in his right eye after being poked, but, luckily enough, Heise has a third eye.

“It was funny — with about a minute and a half left, I went up to (teammate Jamarion Batemon),” Heise said, “and I told him either him or I are going to have a 3 in the corner, and it’s going to win us the game.”

Which is exactly what happened.

Trailing by two, Iowa State saw its possession break down, looking destined to fail as Joshua Jefferson had the ball at the top of the key without much chance of making a play himself with the shot clock barreling toward zero. The virtuoso passing big man, though, made the perfect skip pass to the corner, where Heise caught it and seemingly released it in the same motion.

“(The Cougars) take away a lot of things, but sometimes that backside skip is open,” Heise said of how he came to the prediction he shared with Batemon.

Still, he had to make the dang thing.

“It was one of the easier mindset things because you really have no other choice,” Heise said. “You’re not going to be able to pass the ball — there's not enough time. When you’ve got no other choice, it’s muscle memory.”

Heise’s triple will be the moment that lasts from this game, but it arrived only because of so many that led up to it.

Like Batemon's own 3 in the corner on the previous possession, one that sort of arrived by chance. Iowa State coach T.J. Otzelberger was trying to get Batemon out of the game for Milan Momcilovic, but the 51% 3-point shooter didn’t get to the scorer’s table early. Then Houston’s Milos Uzan missed the front-end of a one-and-one, so in Batemon stayed.

Then he buried a triple, and Momcilovic headed back to the bench to watch his teammate and fellow Milwaukee metro native finish the game.

“(Momcilovic looked at me and he said, ‘You want me to go back to the bench?’” Otzelberger said. “Almost like he was halfway up already saying, let him go, he’s looking good.’

“That speaks to what a great leader and teammate Milan is.”

If we’re talking about great leaders and teammates, though, Tamin Lipsey gets top billing.

The Ames native and Iowa State senior made the type of plays only he can time and again for the Cyclones, giving the type of boost you wouldn't have even thought possible.

“There’s no script when Tamin’s out there,” Otzelberger said. “He just finds a way to make plays nobody else has seen a guy make.”

The most important of which came with four seconds remaining.

Blake Buchanan, a 44% free-throw shooter, stepped to the line to try to improve upon Iowa State’ two-point lead. But, as 44% free-throw shooters often do, Buchanan missed the front-end.

Cue the "Mighty Mouse" music, though, because here Lipsey comes to save the day, swooping in to steal the rebound and the win.

Which, crazily enough, was the third time Iowa State got an offensive rebound on a free throw.

And if that’s not zany enough for you, how about the Cyclones playing the last 18 minutes of the game without a turnover against a Houston team that ranks among the nation’s best at creating turnovers.

The Cyclones needed it all against a truly terrific Houston team that matched the Cyclones punch for punch for almost the entire evening. Both teams are no-doubt Final Four contenders.

But when Heise's 3 found the net, and Hilton Coliseum got as loud as I’ve heard it since the 21-point second-half comeback against Oklahoma in 2015, the Cyclones proved themselves just a little bit better on their homecourt.

“That’s how you win,” Sampson said.

Then, when that final one comes, you make that one, too, and collect all the glory, memories and possibilities that come along with it.

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Iowa State basketball beats No. 2 Houston in instant classic

title: John Fury’s Carl Froch tirade brings chaotic reminder of the Tyson Fury carnival
description: Comment: The press conference for Tyson Fury’s latest return brought garish clothes, a screaming father, and flashes of vulnerability
fullText:
At the six-week mark of 2026, a dispiriting statistic circulated: in the UK, it had rained every single day of the year so far. And as another downpour drenched the pitch at Tottenham Hotspur Stadium, the turf dozing between football matches, Tyson Fury will have surely yearned for spring more than most. After all, it is the season of rebirth, and it will take on another meaning when Fury renews his career for the fifth time.

On 11 April, Fury and Arslanbek Makhmudov will return to Tottenham for Fury’s first bout since December 2024, as he emerges from retirement yet again to fight on Netflix. First, though, the Briton and the Russian visited the stadium for a press conference on Monday, where Fury made numerous revelations.

The “depressing” rain had driven him to Thailand to train; Anthony Joshua’s involvement in a tragic car crash had informed his decision to return to boxing; he will be without a coach as he prepares for Makhmudov; and he wishes to fight three times this year.

It was vintage Fury, veering from vulnerable to fanciful. But all in all... it was good to have him back.

These pages have long expressed a certain scepticism about Fury’s numerous retirements, as well as empathy for fans who have tired of the “Gypsy King” carnival. So yes, Monday’s press conference did hoist a few shoulders into shrugs. However, in the interest of fairness, it must be said that there were moments in which Fury’s charisma was captivating.

The 37-year-old’s energy was palpable as he spoke to The Independent and other publications in a suite at Tottenham, sporting a bright blue waistcoat and a garish tie adorned with the Netflix logo. In one moment, he asked an interviewer in the corner of the room to wrap things up with his dad, John, to eliminate distractions. Yet in another, he took a video call from old foe Derek Chisora, whose grinning face filled the phone screen of Fury’s manager.

Back and forth Fury and Chisora went, as they did in the ring three times, discussing this month’s “cheating” accusations against the Gypsy King – accusations from Deontay Wilder, who was twice beaten by Fury and next faces Chisora in London. “Why are you letting that big slink talk bad about me?” Fury laughed. “If he’d talked bad about you like that, I would have taken his lips off!”

It was the last we saw of Chisora, but not “Big John”. Later in the day, Fury’s father paraded himself around the venue, propelling tirades at anyone who would (despite their best efforts) listen. Former world champion Carl Froch, standing on a podium as a pundit, was the main target of John’s barbs. Froch, appearing to see John coming, had already told a member of his team to get a phone camera ready. Even Independent columnist Steve Bunce had to quell John’s... well, fury. “I’m your friend, John,” was Steve’s calm response to a, “What are you looking at?!” from the livid patriarch.

This was the more tiresome side to the Fury carnival, of course.

Perhaps John craved gasps, but sighs and rolling eyes were all he got. When the press conference started, John was sitting next to his son, only to make an announcement within seconds that he had “made” his “point” and would be making way for Spencer Brown. John beckoned Fury’s manager out of the front row and up to the stage, where Brown should have been sitting all along.

Then came the main event, as John’s son answered questions with lines upon lines, as if someone had accidentally leant on a laptop keyboard for minutes on end.

But again, there was an essence of entertainment in much of what Fury said. Some of it was repeated, almost word for word, from what he’d told us in his suite earlier in the day, but he had saved us some tidbits.

Of Joshua’s crash in December, and the effect it had on their loosely-planned showdown this year, he said: “What happened with ‘AJ’ is a terrible tragedy, and I wish him nothing but the best. If he decides to continue boxing, then good luck to him, and if he decides to finish boxing, even more good luck to him. But it’s not a time to say I want to fight him.

“It hasn’t changed my plan. I need to take my career for myself, I am not interested in the rest of the heavyweight division. I can only concentrate on me. If I can get through Makhmudov, then we can see where we go next.”

Of the upcoming second season of At Home With The Furys, his Netflix reality show, he said: “I would assume it’s going to be April, before the fight. It would make sense, wouldn’t it, to get millions of views for the reality TV show?” And then? “Then millions of views with the documentary, the biopic documentary.”

Indeed, these upcoming releases – including a more serious documentary on Fury – were longstanding clues that the former heavyweight champ would return to the ring this year.

"That’d be like double views," Fury said, “and then all of a sudden: bang! He fights in a few days as well. Makes a lot of sense. I think this will be one of the biggest fights ever recorded, like in terms of views on television, if that makes sense.”

It does make sense. While Fury’s return may not reach the tens of millions who saw Jake Paul vs Joshua, or Paul vs Mike Tyson, it should still be Fury’s most-watched fight ever – such is the ubiquity of Netflix. Until then, the Fury carnival continues, for better and worse.

title: U.S. women's figure skating gets star treatment with Taylor Swift intro
description: The 'Blade Angels' and the 14-time Grammy winner are the perfect combination.
fullText:
The Olympic figure skating ice turns over to the ladies Tuesday in Italy as the short program kicks off at 12:45 p.m. ET. The trio of American women have high expectations, hoping to make it to the medal podium after the competition concludes with Thursday's free skate.

Dubbed the "Blade Angels," the United States squad is made up of Amber Glenn, Alysa Liu and Isabeau Levito. Instead of being rivals, the talented trio have become good friends, each having a chance to earn an American woman an individual Olympic figure skating since Sasha Cohen won the silver in 2006. Glenn and Liu already have a gold medal under their belts from this game, participating in the team event.

With excitement mounting for Tuesday's event, things got even more exciting with the release of a promo video narrated by none other than Taylor Swift.

Amber. Alysa. Isabeau.

Let @taylorswift13 introduce you to the Blade Angels: Three American showgirls on ice. #WinterOlympics pic.twitter.com/rj4K3v5T3F

— NBC Olympics & Paralympics (@NBCOlympics) February 16, 2026

The video was themed similarly to Swift's latest album, The Life Of A Showgirl, and detailed each of their journeys to this point.

This article originally appeared on For The Win: U.S. women's figure skating gets star treatment with Taylor Swift intro

title: 🐣 Young talent of the week: Jesse Bisiwu 🇧🇪
description: As every week, OneFootball shines a spotlight on a young talent on the rise.This week, we're heading to Belgium, to Bruges, to discover Jesse Bisiwu, who has already caught Barça's eye... Belgium is...
fullText:
As every week, OneFootball shines a spotlight on a young talent on the rise.

This week, we're heading to Belgium, to Bruges, to discover Jesse Bisiwu, who has already caught Barça's eye...

Belgium is a true talent factory in the world of football. And the new winger who could soon terrorize the best European defenses might just be Jesse Bisiwu.

The 18-year-old Belgian quickly climbed the ranks at his training club in Bruges. Since the age of 15, he has played with the club's reserves in the Belgian second division, also taking part in Youth League matches where he has made quite an impression.

A physical winger (1.82m) but very agile and fast, known for his ball control and ability to beat opponents with his dribbling, he was a standout performer at the U17 Euro last May, leading Belgium to the semi-finals. He was even named to the tournament's team of the tournament.

His qualities have quickly caught the attention of top European clubs, especially Barça, who are closely monitoring the player, as confirmed by his agent. It's an obvious connection on paper, further highlighted by comments from a Ghanaian scout (the country of his origins), who stated that his playing style is "similar to that of Lamine Yamal".

Bisiwu remains a player with great potential, who has not yet tested himself at the highest level, but his qualities as a modern winger—cutting in sharply from the left and very strong in possession—make him an ideal target for the Catalan club.

There is no doubt that we should soon see this livewire at a big club, as his contract with Bruges runs until 2027.

This article was translated into English by Artificial Intelligence. You can read the original version in 🇫🇷 here.

title: 3 takeaways | LSU baseball beats Kent State on Monday night
description: LSU baseball's Jake Brown is on fire. Here are three takeaways from the Tigers' Monday night win over Kent State.
fullText:
We're only four games into LSU baseball's 2026 season, but at this point, it's Jake Brown's world, and we're all just living in it. Brown homered twice more on Monday night, making it back-to-back multi-home run games for the junior.

Whatever routine Brown is on, LSU needs him to keep doing it.

After yesterday's win over Milwaukee, Jay Johnson had this to say about Brown's hot start so far.

Jay Johnson on Jake Brown's incredible start to the 2026 #LSU baseball season pic.twitter.com/hYayJmZvcU

— Mike Scarborough (@ScarboroughMike) February 16, 2026

Brown is not the only Tiger swinging the bat well, though. LSU was able to crack double digits on the scoreboard in back-to-back nights, and they have now scored 10 or more runs in three out of their first four games. That is a recipe for success going forward.

Let's take a look at three takeaways from today's win over Kent State

JAKE BROWN…AGAIN!!! 💣💣 https://t.co/rA3hE2mhhK pic.twitter.com/8gMey57DPX

— LSU Baseball Data (@LSUBaseballData) February 17, 2026

The answer to that question is that he can generate 8 RBI and hit four homers in a span of 24 hours. Brown is on fire right now. He's already scored 17 runs and racked up 23 total bases in 2026.

Bye Bye Baseball 👋@zach_yorke | SECN + pic.twitter.com/sklp3Kpb4U

— LSU Baseball (@LSUbaseball) February 17, 2026

Yorke terrorizes baseballs. He homered again on Monday night, his second long shot of the year. Yorke is slugging .909 in the early going, already with 10 total bases on the year. LSU brought in the veteran transfer to supply power to the lineup and that's just what Yorke has done so far.

Strike 'Em Out Looking 👀@GavinGuidry5 | SECN + pic.twitter.com/xSQV17qjye

— LSU Baseball (@LSUbaseball) February 17, 2026

Along with thousands of other Tiger fans, I was ecstatic to get to see Gavin Guidry back on the mound. Two years ago, I thought he was one of the best pitchers in the country, and then LSU lost him for all of 2025. So far this year, Guidry has faced 14 hitters, and he has struck out 10 of them while allowing only one hit. He is one of the best arms in college baseball, bar none.

This article originally appeared on LSU Wire: Three takeaways from LSU baseball's win over Kent State

title: England wing Arundell free to play against Ireland
description: England wing Henry Arundell is available for Saturday's Six Nations clash with Ireland at Twickenham after his red card last weekend.
fullText:
England wing Henry Arundell is available for Saturday's Six Nations clash with Ireland at Twickenham after his red card last weekend.

The 23-year-old had a disciplinary hearing on Tuesday after he was shown two yellow cards in the 31-20 Six Nations defeat by Scotland.

Arundell was sin-binned for not releasing his opponent early on in the match and then received a second yellow for taking out Kyle Steyn in the air.

The Bath wing received an automatic 20-minute red card that meant his team-mates played with 14 men for a total of 30 minutes.

The hearing found that "no further sanction was appropriate".

A statement said: "The player accepted that he had committed the acts of foul play that resulted in the showing of the two yellow cards.

"In the circumstances (including that the first yellow card had been issued for a 'technical offence', and that the second yellow card had been issued for a very different act of foul play), [it was decided that] the sending off of the player had been a sufficient sanction."

Arundell has scored four tries in two games - a hat-trick against Wales and England's opening try at Murrayfield.

His place could still be taken by Tommy Freeman or Elliot Daly when the side is announced later on Tuesday.

Immanuel Feyi-Waboso is likely to miss the rest of the tournament through injury.

title: Ilia Malinin gets exciting Simone Biles news at the Olympics
description: The figure skating star gets some company.
fullText:
Ilia Malinin gets exciting Simone Biles news at the Olympics originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Ilia Malinin is going to get a cool opportunity on Tuesday at the Olympics.

He's slated to be on the Today Show, and the Team USA figure skating star won't be alone.

The show is also scheduled to have legendary gymnast Simone Biles make an appearance.

Ilia Malinin will appear alongside the seven-time Olympic champion Simone Biles on the TODAY show today (February 17). pic.twitter.com/Q4iRdb08Z8

— Ilia Malinin Daily (@TheIliaSociety) February 17, 2026

MORE: U.S. women's hockey star's brothers go viral at Olympics

It's not clear from the announcement whether the two Olympians will appear together or just within the same show.

Still, it's really cool for Malinin after a disappointment in the men's individual competition at these Games.

The pre-Olympics favorite for the gold medal, Malinin took a lead from the short program into the free skate, too. But then multiple falls bumped him all the way down to an eighth-place finish.

Biles knows unexpected Olympic disappointment, too, and she proved that a superstar athlete can come back from that four years later and perform to the best of their ability again.

Malinin can certainly take some lessons from that journey.

He seems to have mostly handled this tough moment in his career with composure and class.

Malinin is also sticking around Italy, because he plans to skate in the exhibition gala over the weekend. That's often just for medalists, but evidently the Olympics decided having Malinin in it would be a good idea.

It'll be a while until Malinin gets a chance at total redemption. But one day at a time right now, he's doing what he can to get himself back on track.
